div1.p: Exhibit "A"

The justice having opened court, the names of the witnesses were called out, and as the persons came in they were sent to the witness; room. H. B. Lockwood, a brother of M. Lockwood, deceased, a seat near the prosecuting attorney.
The first witness called was A.H. Thompson, who was sworn, and in answer to interrogatories of the prosecuting attorney, testified as follows:

I live in Tacoma, and have resided here since last August; am night yardmaster; between 2 and 3 o'clock on the morning of the 16th, I was on a train between the wharf and the top of the hill; after 2 o'clock we were going up the grade, with a car of live stock for the slaughterhouse; I was sitting in the engine cab, on the fireman's side, which is on this side of track; saw an object moving on left of track, and moving away from a black object; I thought the latter was an overcoat; I kept my eyes on the object, until, when the fireman opened the firebox door, the fire blinded me and prevented me from seeing; the engine was about thirty feet distant form the object when it disappeared from my view; when we struck the object I felt it, and called the engineer to stop; this was 2:30; when the engine stopped I got off first and ran back; I knew it must have been a dog or something we ran over; as I neared the place I saw a dog leaving; I found a man on the track: the body was laying face down, on the inside of the track, close to the rail. the engine and car had run over feet and shoulders; the head was close to the rail, with the face turned to the center of the track; the feet were crossed, the left foot was over the rail, the right on the inside; did not examine his feet; the body looked like that of a man lately killed; the eyes were there was a hole in the forehead, from which no blood was coming out; looked at the man with a tanern, and knew he was a man I had seen about town; saw no marks except those described; a gargling noise came from the body; I saw light and called out to the person with the light; he said he was Kelly; told him we had run over a man, but did not know his name; Kelly came up; the body lay in the same position after being run over, as I saw it before; heard no noise we were going south at the time, up grade, the engine pulling the car; I looked over the engine afterwards, but found to signs of blood or hair; the distance from ash pan to wheel of engine is about six inches; I did not examine the car until yesterday, [Sunday], when I found blood on all the wheels; the brakebeam on the engine is higher than the steps and could have passed over the body without touching it; had the clothes on the body caught it would have been mangled; the coatflap was turned up a little; the engine must have struck the foot first; the body did not bleed freely; was going to take the body, but the others who had come up objected; did not examine body very closely, and did not put hands on it; sent a man down after coroner, or a constable; appeared to me as though the man had been alive when struck, though I saw no twitching of the muscles; the man might have raised his head and might have been struck by a bolt, and his forehead might have struck a spike; we took the car down to the slaughter house unloaded it and when we got back the body was on the outside and other side of the track; there is a roadway across the track, about thirty-five yards from where the body lay.

Cross examined: The switch engine, with light at both ends, was backing up with car of live stock, going at the rate of eight or nine miles an hour; there is a good roadbed there; track is level between ties, and is in a out and on a curve; the cut is about 115 feet deep; can see about 90 feet ahead on lower side of curve; saw a small gray dog moving away from object; did not see any movement by the object as the track; the train ran about 80 feet beyond the body before it stopped; there as not much of a grade at this point; did not see the arm bleeding; saw blood on the tie; the wound in the forehead was like a dent, the skin was not broken, and wound not bleeding; there was blood on
Exhibit "A"
the face; a piece of the skull lay on the side of the track ; he might have raised his head, put it back again, and a spike might have struck his forehead.

Re-direct: Think head lay on a tie; saw blood on right and left of rails where the shoulder and the feet would be; couldn't fall when Olympian arrived; had no occasion for remembering; the wound on forehead was between the eyes, V-shaped; did not examine it closely; such a hole would be made by a rock between the ties; it could not have been made only by a spike; the skin of forehead wound was not broken; did not examine wound in back of head.
Re-cross: The forehead wound was of a shape as would be the head of a railroad spike.
William Vail, being sworn, corroborated the testimony of first witness as to the train;s running up the hill, and the

location of the body; he was on the upside of the engine; could not see as far as Thompson, from up-side; heard Thompson call out "Hold her! hold her!" reversed his engine; felt the wheels rise and drop, but heard no noise; this was at 2:30 a.m. on Tuesday; after Thompson got off the engine, he waited awhile, about 1 1/2 minutes, and then went down the track, where he saw the body; he heard no noise come from the body; supposed the man was dead; the face was down and turned towards center of track; two feet were on rail; the wheels passed diagonally over the feet, cleared the body and then again ran on the arm and shoulder; the ashpan on the engine could not have struck him, and if he made no struggle, everything but the wheels would be clear of the body; he thought they ought to send for the coroner; he saw blood at the place; knew the dead man by sight; the night was dark and slightly foggy, and could not see object on track from his place on the engine; supposed they had run over the man and killed him; went back to his engine and took car up to slaughter house, being gone over and hour; did not wait long at body; would have heard noise if man made any.

Walter Osgood sworn: I live in Tacoma; am fireman on yard engine since the 7th of last November; was firing on the morning of July 16; between 2 and 3 o'clock was on hill between wharf and slaughter house; our train ran over a man; was firing at time, heard Thompson call, "hold her!" and saw Vail throw her over; I thought we had struck something; when engine stopped yardmaster and brakeman went back; I went down and saw a man on the track; knew him by sight; he was named Lockwood; he was lying on his cheek, his face toward center of track, head against the rial; did not touch body; supposed him to be dead; we put a man there to watch, and sent the brakeman for the coroner; looked at the body with the lantern; saw gash on forehead, it was bleeding; heard no noise; body did not move; the man was perfectly dead; it was two or three minutes after we stopped that I got off engine; the body was not bleeding freely; heard no noise when we passed over body; could see further ahead on my side than the engineer could on his; the engine could pass over the prostrate body, the car might not; Vail, Thompson, Kirkbride and Winslow were on the train.
Cross-examined Was never before on a train running over a man.

J. W. Kirkbride sworn: I am a brakeman and have been sin e the 1st of June; between 2 and 3 o'clock on morning of 16th, went from wharf to stockyard, train struck the body about 2:30; was on the car lying down, when I heard engine stop; knew the engine was reversed by the sound of escaping steam; put on the brake; heard Thompson say, "Billy, you ran over something;" said man was run over;

looked at the body not more than five minutes after it was struck. [He here described the position of the body.] Saw a piece of skull on ground; the head was between the ties; saw no movement of body nor did I touch it; appeared to be dead; head was against the rail, saw no mark on face until at then saw gash, which seemd cut to bone; the skin was broken, a timber under tank frame of engine was low down, but do not know whether it would touch body or not; the clothing on body was not torn, and body was covered with dust; heard no noise when we struck the body and felt no jar.

Cross-examined: A piece of the skull was knocked off; piece half as big as my hand. [Witness illustrated about where the piece of skull was gone on the head.] If the man had raised his head it is likely he would have been struck where piece of skull was off.

Jay W. Kelly sworn: Live in Tacoma; am a nightwatchman at pumping station of water works; heard train stop about 2:30 a. m. on morning of 16th; somebody called to him and said there was a man on the track; went up and saw man on track; face of body was down; saw that the feet were mangled; saw a hole in the head of body, and supposed it to have been cut by the flange of the wheel; saw blood on the left cheek; did not touch the body; saw the trainmen, but did not know the party who came up there afterwards; Mr. Walker's folks told me who it was that was killed; I heard voices at the Walker house; called twice, but they did not hear me call at first; I said a dead man was on the track and described the dog that was there; they said it must be Lockwood's dog' M. A. Walker, his wife and brother came down on track; said that was Lockwood; they thought the man's folks ought to know about it; after I was called I got to the place within five minutes; the Walker's were dressed when they came to the track; Mrs. Walker took hold of Lockwood's hand or wrist; I said "I wouldn't touch it;" she said it would do no harm; I said I suppose it will not; I saw no movement of body; was there from five to ten minutes after train stopped; the Walker house is a few yards to northwest of place where body was found; place where body lay is southeast of house; there is a medium curved track; I could not tell what the voices were saying in the house; the two Walkers came on the track about the same time; think the married man was first if any one; the trainmen asked me to stay by the body while they sent after coroner, and I did so until he came about three-quarters of an hour later; feet of body must have been on the rail; did not notice head nor notice body bleeding.

Cross-examined: The place where the body lay was a few yards from the Walkers' house; I called twice, " Mr. Walker"; could see house from where I stood; I said, "there is a man on the track and a dog here"; I described dog; they said it must be Lockwood's; think the married man came down the bank first; a man would naturally have to one down the bank fast, as it is steep.
At this juncture, 12:20 p. m., the court took a recess for one hour.

W. E. Hunter, sworn, testified as follows: Live in Tacoma; have been a resident for two years; am a painter; acquainted a short time with defendants; have met them three times; was at the Walker house on night of 15th and 16th of July; want there on Wednesday, July 15; went there with Mr. Dolan, Mrs. Dolan, Miss Arnold, Mrs. Hunter (my wife) and myself; found
